body.head.byline: By SUNNY VANDERBECK; Written with David Leonhardt.

abstract.p: The Boss column profiles Sunny Vanderbeck, chief executive of Data Return, which runs Web software; Vanderbeck comments; photo (M)

block.p: I'm 27, and I spent the first years of my life on a farm outside Fort Worth. I've always been curious. One time, when I was 4, I wanted to get into a locked room. So I got a screwdriver and took the doorknob off.

As I reached third grade, it became clear it was time for me to go live with my dad. Dads tend to be a little bit more structured, a little less touchy-feely. Still, school bored me. I'd get discounted on a paper because I didn't follow the procedure. And I'd say to the teachers, ''But I got to the answer faster.'' They didn't care. My attitude was, ''whatever.''

I'm 27, and I spent the first years of my life on a farm outside Fort Worth. I've always been curious. One time, when I was 4, I wanted to get into a locked room. So I got a screwdriver and took the doorknob off.

As I reached third grade, it became clear it was time for me to go live with my dad. Dads tend to be a little bit more structured, a little less touchy-feely. Still, school bored me. I'd get discounted on a paper because I didn't follow the procedure. And I'd say to the teachers, ''But I got to the answer faster.'' They didn't care. My attitude was, ''whatever.''

To satisfy my curiosity, I'd try things out. My freshman year in high school, I was a member of R.O.T.C. My sophomore year, I had a mohawk. Later, I got early admission to the University of Texas at Arlington. There were things I missed, like senior prom, but those functions never held a lot of interest for me.

Neither did college, it turned out. I remember writing PASCAL computer programs that told you how much change -- pennies, nickels, dimes -- you should return after a transaction. I was bored out of my mind. So, like that Monty Python skit, I started thinking, ''And now for something completely different.''

I went to talk to the military recruiters. But none of the jobs looked interesting except counterintelligence, and until you're pretty senior in counterintelligence, you're basically a gofer. The next day I realized I wanted to try to become an Airborne Ranger in the Army. There aren't that many Rangers, and the washout rate is tremendous. It sounded like an amazing challenge.

After we had learned how to jump out of airplanes, we went into the Ranger indoctrination program. These are basically three weeks to see if you really want to be a Ranger or if you thought it sounded cool. We crawled through the mud in the middle of the night. We did push-ups until we couldn't push anymore and then rolled over and did flutter kicks until we couldn't do any more and then rolled back over and did push-ups.
It was constant, incessant physical, mental and emotional harassment. I wasn't bored anymore, that's for sure.

Because I had done hunting as a kid, they made me a sniper. Sometimes we'd get on a plane at dusk, go do something in another country and be back at dawn. I never shot anyone, though. It was almost all training exercises. You get this mindset that ''I'm a Ranger.'' Everything else becomes irrelevant. But by the end of my time, I would look at my bunkmate and think, ''Is his life worth a mission that may not affect the quality of life in the United States?'' I wasn't sure.

Ranger school prepared me more than anything else for what I do now -- managing in the controlled chaos of the Internet. If you can execute a mission under stress and motivate people who are worn down, then getting a group of people -- who did eat today and did sleep last night -- aligned around a common vision is not that difficult.

After the Army, I went back to college, but I dropped out again to take a job at Microsoft. Then, Microsoft made a hard left to respond to the Internet. That drove me and two colleagues to start our company. Our venture capitalists were our American Express and Visa cards.

Microsoft taught us to focus on the long term. Our stock is worth about a third of what it was in March. But we know we're building something. A stock price is like climbing up a ladder with a yo-yo. If you watch the yo-yo, you'll miss the big picture.
